Award.AwardTitle: EAGER:COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Metagenomic Analysis to ensure water quality and safety

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1742869/ 1742870
Huq; Leddy

With increased water scarcity, it is critical that safe water supplies be maintained, including wastewater for environmental discharge or reuse. Currently microbial (bacterial and viral) water quality is measured using standard microbiological and biotechnological culture methods to establish safe water quality. This proposed EAGER is transformative as the study aims to explore the use of a newly developed detailed and sensitive metagenomic sequence analysis to understand and identify microbial communities for accurate determination of biological water quality in water, wastewater, biofilms, and water reuse systems.

With the proposed metagenomic analysis system, microorganisms, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and parasites, will be accurately identified to species and strains. Additionally, antibiotic resistance and pathogenicity properties are also identified to evaluate diversity and abundance of the genes and microorganisms in-situ. By assessing the microbial communities and comparing their composition, a better understanding of the microbial communities and their ecology is developed to provide improved methods for assessing microbial water quality for indirect potable reuse and direct potable reuse. Culture-dependent methods and indicator microorganism measurements have proven to be slow and biased because they do not represent all species, often not even the dominant species present during advanced water and wastewater treatment. Molecular techniques have provided insights into microbial community structure; however, these methods are seriously limited because they target single microorganisms that are often the less dominant species. Therefore, with metagenomic analysis using next generation sequencing, accurate resolution of the microbial communities and their diversity is achieved, resulting in significant benefits for environmental and public health applications. Metagenomic whole DNA sequencing involves shearing all DNA in a sample that is then sequenced by next generation sequencing. Next generation sequencing is non-discriminatory, identifying all organisms, even the underrepresented, while identifying functional and resistant genes, pathogenicity, and providing taxonomic structure based on phylogenetic trees, all in a single analysis and within approximately one day. Therefore, next generation sequencing provides a more complete identification, with greater resolution of the microbial community and its ecology. The results from this study have the potential of defining microbial communities in water systems at each step of the process and will transform the ability to understand and design better indicators, validate surrogates, and also define sustainable microbial communities beneficial for drinking water and water reuse. The long term societal impact will be paramount as the proposed project will yield a more defined microbial community structure for water quality and safe water supplies and will demonstrate the utility of this important, emerging approach for the water and water reuse industry. During the course of this study, a doctoral student will gain fundamental and applied knowledge in the area of bioinformatics and water reuse that encompasses advanced treatment technologies that are employed in water reuse. Student interns will have the opportunity to learn field sampling techniques. This study will establish a good foundation to achieve notable broader impacts for the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Generally, it is estimated that more than 2 billion people lack safe drinking water. A major challenge is being able to measure water quality, specifically the safety of drinking water.  Microbiological water quality is traditionally measured by using culture-based methods to detect and enumerate indicator organisms. Culture methods are time-consuming and often do not provide sufficient detail to determine the presence of all species of microorganisms of importance that may be present in a sample. Metagenomic sequencing analysis, which does not provide inferences about viability or the infectious potential of detected microbial species, does, however, utilizes the total DNA in a sample to detect accurately and identify all microorganisms in a sample, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protists, to a sub-species level and characterize them. That is, this approach detects genes that code for antimicrobial resistance, virulence, and metabolic properties in a sample that may not be routinely detected by growth-based assays. In this EAGER project, we introduced an alternative method to microbial culture by employing metagenomic sequencing technology to detect, identify, and characterize bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protists using the genetic material recovered directly from potable and non-potable water.

 A total of 17 samples were collected from a variety of water sources, including municipal tap water, public drinking fountain water, commercially available bottled water, untreated groundwater used for produce farming, and samples from various treatment steps throughout water reuse systems from two wastewater treatment facilities. Non-commercial samples were transported to the laboratory on cool packs to minimize the possibility of growth. All samples were concentrated by filtration within two hours of collection, DNA extracted from the resulting biomass, and metagenomic sequencing performed to determine the presence of microorganisms in each of the samples.

 All of the potable water samples (tap water, drinking fountain water, and bottled water) contained microbiomes that comprised mainly common soil and water bacteria. The presence of opportunistic human pathogens was detected only rarely. No indicator bacteria (Escherichia coli or enterococci) were detected in any of the potable water samples. More bacterial species were detected in tap water than in bottled water, however, with the largest number of microorganisms detected in a municipal tap water supply. Amongst all bottled water samples, more genetic material was recovered from bottled mineral water, compared to bottled spring water and reprocessed tap water. Very few viruses, protists, or fungi were detected in the potable water samples and these were bacteriophages that attack bacteria and are not harmful to humans. DNA encoding virulence factors were detected only at very low numbers in the potable water samples, and did not indicate a risk of infection. No antibiotic resistance markers were detected in any of the potable water samples. 

 All of the non-potable water samples collected from the wastewater treatment plants were found to have the frequency and abundance of bacteria, viruses, protists, and fungi dramatically reduced in each of the steps in the water treatment process. The observed reduction in microbiological content provides proof-of-concept that the wastewater treatment processes are effective in reducing organic composites, namely the microbial populations, as expected. Very little genetic material was recovered from the samples of untreated groundwater used in vegetable agriculture. The dominant bacterium detected is commonly found in fermented foods that paramedical companies employ in their probiotic products. No fungi, protists, virulence factors, or antibiotic resistance markers were detected in the untreated groundwater samples.

Implementation of this method for determining microbiological safety will provide an alternative to traditional biological water-quality monitoring methods that rely heavily on culturing indicator microorganisms and fail to detect the presence of microorganisms present in addition to indicator bacteria, as well as virulence associated markers. Results of this project will be useful in developing alternative wastewater treatment protocols, especially for targeting specific pathogens and could also be useful in improving personal protective equipment as well as working conditions. This report is one of the first to provide metagenomic data on finished water, e.g., bottled drinking water, thus offering a baseline for drinking water quality.

Intellectual Merit: In this investigation, we defined composition of the microbiota present in samples collected from water, wastewater, and water reuse systems.  The findings can be used to introduce an alternative protocol that is more precise and faster than traditional culture-based methods for determining microbial water quality. This EAGER project supported a doctoral student working with expert team members from industry who provided training in sample collection, NGS library preparation, high throughput bioinformatics, and comparative analysis, as well as education in many aspects of water reuse. The data generated in this project will ultimately become a part of the student’s Ph. D. dissertation and the skill set acquired by the student will be applied throughout his career.
